The story of ViÅ›vakarman. The World-Honored One said to the great king:
You should listen attentively!

In the past, for the sake of seeking unsurpassed perfect enlightenment and benefiting sentient beings, there was a wheel-turning sage king named MahÄpraá¹‡Äda, who was endowed with the seven treasures, attained the four kinds of unobstructed cognition, and extensively distinguished and explained in the sixty-third chapter of the Long Ä€gama Sutras.

At that time, King Praá¹‡Äda was doubly fond of the true Dharma. He offered food and drink to five hundred pratyekabuddhas, and after offering food and drink, he gave each of them a fine piece of cloth, and spoke a verse, saying:
Having attained a vast mind, virtuous ones, do not be negligent;
Giving to those who uphold the precepts, giving will surely bring increase.
This giving is clear and penetrating, with faith one attains liberation;
By attaining a mind free from guilt, one will give rise to joy and happiness.
At that time, the Buddha said to the great king:
Do not have any other thoughts!
The wheel-turning king who possessed the seven treasures and attained the four supernatural powers at that time is none other than I myself.
At that time, although I made this act of giving and did not attain supreme perfect enlightenment,
Because of this cause and condition, I accumulated wholesome roots. Therefore, I have now attained perfect enlightenment.
The Buddha further said to the great king:
I sought supreme perfect enlightenment and made acts of giving and meritorious deeds. You should listen attentively!
In the past, there was a brahmin named Timely, who was of a great and wealthy family. He always practiced giving and gave Dharma to the brahmins.
He used 840,000 great elephants, adorned with golden ornaments, all covered with pure golden banners, with golden nets hanging down, all decorated with gold.
This elephant was given to the Brahmins and others, as explained in the VÄ«ramahÄyÄna SÅ«tra, like the MadhyamÄgama SÅ«tra.
Having made this merit, he spoke a verse, saying:
Having given, I wish them happiness, I give while abiding in fearlessness;
With giving, I make offerings to the world, to the gods and all people.
If seeking all happiness, abandoning giving while abiding in fearlessness;
One can seek and attain liberation, greatly wealthy, becoming a ruler of men.
The Buddha told the great king:
The Brahmin of the highest caste who gave eighty-four thousand golden adorned elephants at that time is none other than I myself.
At that time, because of my abandonment and giving, I had not yet realized unsurpassed perfect supreme enlightenment;
Because of that cause and condition, there was a condition of right faith, and therefore now my merit is complete, and I have attained unsurpassed perfect supreme enlightenment.
Moreover, Your Majesty, I, seeking unsurpassed perfect supreme enlightenment, was able to practice giving and create blessings and benefits.
Your Majesty, listen carefully!
Long ago, there was a wheel-turning king named Jitasena, who ruled the four continents, was endowed with the seven treasures, had the three kinds of supernormal knowledge, and had no heir.
Because of seeking an heir, he contemplated creating a thousand expedients.
At that time, a person came and said to the king:
'There is a medicine called many sons, if the palace ladies eat it, they will have sons.'
The king, having heard the name of the medicine many sons, immediately sought it out.
Later, the king obtained this medicine, finely ground it, and had it taken by the palace ladies. After drinking it, they immediately became pregnant.
The queen did not know this matter, and after ten months, she gave birth to a son. His appearance was dignified, his face was like a lion, and he had the divine power of Narayana.
He gathered his relatives and held a birthday celebration, naming him Kusha.
At that time, in front of the prince, there naturally appeared a wonderful conch and a wheel.
If the prince blew and struck this conch, the outer army would hear it and all flee;
Or if they heard it, their ears would immediately become deaf.
If they heard the sound of the turning wheel, people would all run and hide or fall into houses and caves.
Having conquered the outer realm, the kings surrendered and came to see the father king, saying:
Great King!
All the kings of the outer realm, I have subdued them all.
When the father king heard this, he was overjoyed and immediately had the prince marry a princess from a neighboring country.
Divining the auspicious stars, he gathered his relatives to perform the wedding ceremony.
The princess, seeing the prince's frightening appearance, was terrified and ran away.
At that time, the prince immediately held the conch, wheel, and sword in his hands, and chased after her. On the way, he saw the elephants and horses of the royal family being eaten by lions.
At that time, the people guarding the elephants and horses all came to tell the prince:
Now the elephants and horses are being eaten by lions. Please save them.
We have our own private elephants and horses. We will give you one-sixth of them.
At that time, the prince immediately blew the conch, and the lions and tigers all fled.
At that time, the prince said to the people:
As for the one-sixth that I am entitled to, I will wait until I return.
Having said this, he chased after the princess. Her relatives and soldiers followed after him, and the prince said:
Turn back.
If you insist on leaving, take the soldiers and go to your wife's family.
The prince said:
'I will go alone now, without needing an army.'
Having said this, the army turned back, and the prince proceeded alone.
Later, when he arrived at the wife's country, the wife's father saw him and said to the prince:
'Take this daughter away.'
Having obtained the daughter, he immediately turned back and went to the place where the elephants were being trained, and said to the trainer:
'Give me one-sixth of it.'
The elephant trainer replied:
'The elephant was blown away by the wind.'
Then the prince spoke a verse, saying:
The elephant in the prime of youth, drunk with madness, was blown away by the wind;
How much more so cattle and sheep, the mind needs to know for itself.
At that time, the prince bathed, applied fragrant medicine to his body, took a mirror to look at his face, and saw that his appearance was terrifying. He then thought like this:
'My face is like this, and people will see me.
What use do I have for this body?
I must kill myself.
He then entered the forest and wanted to kill himself.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, saw that the prince was a bodhisattva in the Bhadrakalpa, and if he killed himself, he would surely suffer greatly.
If I transform him to be handsome, he will not kill himself.
At that time, Åšakra gave the prince a precious pearl in his conch-shaped hair. After wearing it, the prince became like a god, with a handsome appearance, and obtained the seven treasures.

Later, when his father passed away, the prince succeeded to the throne and ruled the four continents in accordance with the Dharma, possessing the seven treasures and having great power as a wheel-turning sage king.
In the six hundred thousand cities, he established halls of righteousness. The people relied on the Dharma to make sacrifices, and exclusively practiced giving for many years.
After many hundreds of thousands of years, having given to all the brahmins, he spoke a verse, saying:
If one has many enjoyments, whether among the gods or humans;
If one does not give with a determined mind, one will not abandon much wealth.
The deluded person is stingy and attached, but when the Buddha appears, one should quickly give;
Holding a staff is not bravery, but the mind of giving is fierce.
The Buddha told the great king:
At that time, I was named the king of the wheel of grass, establishing 600,000 halls of meaning, practicing the method of sacrificial giving, and extensively cultivating merit.
Great king!
Do not have different views, that was my body.
At that time, I was named the king of the wheel of grass.
In this way, all 600,000 cities were built according to worldly customs, sacrificial halls were established for all, and meritorious deeds were cultivated everywhere.
The Buddha told the great king:
I gave rise to the conditions for renunciation, and thus attained unsurpassed perfect supreme enlightenment.
Great king!

Do not have different thoughts, I cultivated this merit, and will realize unsurpassed perfect enlightenment. For the sake of causes and conditions, for the sake of the root of faith, I accumulated good roots.
Furthermore, great king!
I further practiced giving and cultivated blessings in order to seek unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Great King, listen carefully!
Long ago, there was a king named SÅ«ryavamÅ›a, surrounded by hundreds of thousands of relatives.
That king practiced kindness and compassion, benefiting and delighting sentient beings.
When the country was suffering from famine, the king made a vow with truthful words, and the heavens immediately sent down rain, so that the country was always prosperous.
Later, the king renounced his position and became a renunciant, following an ascetic and attaining the five supernatural powers.
At that time, in VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« there was a king named Brahmadatta, who was righteously ruling the country, with the people flourishing, prosperous, and at ease.
Astrologers predicted that after twelve years there would be no rain from the heavens.
The king beat the drum and issued a proclamation to the people, saying:
If you can provide provisions for twelve years, you may stay in this country;
if you cannot, you are free to go elsewhere.
The people in the country discussed among themselves:
Now that there is a famine, what plan should we make?
Where should we go?
Among them, someone said:
I heard that in the country of Matá¹›kÄ, there is a sage who speaks true words and vows, and the gods then send rain, always resulting in abundant harvests and sufficient food and grain.
At that time, the people, because of the lack of food, all went to the country of Matá¹›kÄ.
The prince left home to become a monk, and the prince stayed in the position.
For all the people who came to the country, for twelve years, the provided food and supplies were all sufficient.
King Brahmadatta asked his ministers:
Where are the people in my country now?
The ministers replied:
As explained above, they are in the country of the sage Matá¹›kÄ.
The king then told his ministers:
Now, in times of famine, it is like the end of the eon.
What plans can we make to escape this suffering?'
The ministers replied:
'The god Matá¹›kÄ has now left the household life and attained the path of the immortals. It is fitting to invite him.'
King Brahmadatta then went to the place of the sage Matá¹›kÄ and said to him:
'In my country, there is a severe famine, just like the end of the eon.
I only wish that the great sage would come to my country and make a vow of truth.'
At that time, the sage accepted the invitation and went to the country of King Brahmadatta. He made a vow of truth, saying:
I was born as a caá¹‡á¸Äla, but I have no evil thoughts or intentions to harm;
The words spoken by SanalÄ should be known everywhere, and all gods and humans will see it.ğŸ”½Thus, the true words I speak now,
I have long cultivated the practice of loving-kindness;ğŸ”½For all sentient beings in the Dharma realm,
I wish the dragons to rain and save the hungry people.
From birth until now, the good deeds I have cultivated, for a long time practicing loving-kindness and compassion,
With these immeasurable true words, may the dragon rain down to save sentient beings.
At that time, after the sage made this vow, immediately a great rain fell from the sky in VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, and the famine ended, turning into a year of great harvest.
All the people in the city who had previously gone to the country of Matá¹›kÄ all returned and resumed their former occupations.
The Buddha said to the king:
The king of Matá¹›kÄ, Sanaphala, in the past was none other than myself.
In the past, my mind practiced loving-kindness and compassion, benefiting sentient beings.
If I spoke true words, the heavens would immediately rain, able to end hunger and famine, always resulting in abundant harvests.
Great King!

I did not attain supreme perfect enlightenment merely by giving away my body, but also through cultivating immeasurable meritorious causes and conditions, accumulating wholesome roots, and giving rise to right faith, I attained supreme perfect enlightenment.
The Buddha said to the king:
I practiced giving and created various meritorious deeds in order to seek supreme enlightenment.
Great king, listen attentively!
Long ago, in the country of Midila, there was a wheel-turning king named MahÄdeva.
I have already explained this in detail in the MadhyamÄgama.
The king, seeing that he himself had great enjoyments, performed the rites of sacrifice, and spoke this verse:
If the mind seeks great wealth, in the heavens and among humans;
According to one's ability, one should practice giving, out of fear of poverty.
The giver is revered by people, and later will surely receive heavenly offerings;
Humans and non-humans take refuge in him, like rain can bring forth fruits.
The Buddha told the great king:
Do not have any other thoughts!

At that time, the great god who was the wheel-turning king, determined to go to the good path, always cultivated pure conduct, and for eighty-four thousand lives, he always obtained the position of a wheel-turning king.
Great king!
Do not have any other thoughts, at that time the wheel-turning king was none other than I myself.
Furthermore, great king!
How could I only attain supreme enlightenment through this giving?
But by cultivating immeasurable causes and conditions for meritorious deeds, accumulating wholesome roots, and giving rise to right faith, I attained supreme perfect enlightenment.
The Buddha told the great king:
In the past, for the sake of seeking supreme enlightenment, I practiced giving and created various meritorious deeds.
Great king, listen attentively!
Long ago, in the city of MithilÄ, there was a wheel-turning king named Nimiá¹­ha, whom I also explained in detail in the Ä€gama sÅ«tras.
The king saw himself enjoying great wealth and performing worldly sacrifices, giving to all, and spoke a verse, saying:
If one sees good deeds being done, follow and do good in return;
If one is lazy and does not do them, one is a lowly man.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, told King Nimiá¸a:
You may come to my palace and enjoy the five desires and heavenly pleasures with me, having fun and playing, enjoying pleasures as you wish.
At that time, the king replied in verse, saying:
Just as borrowed utensils from others must be returned when the time limit is up;
Heavenly pleasures are also like this, just like temporarily borrowed things.ğŸ”½I will return to MithilÄ and create much merit;
In the future, in that palace, by inheriting merit, I will be born in the heavens.
At that time, after Mithila returned to his capital city, he practiced giving, created various meritorious deeds, and spoke a verse, saying:
The virtuous praise giving, giving according to the season;
Kshatriyas, Brahmins, Vaishyas, Chandalas, and Sudras.
In times of famine, give, and let the practitioners be satisfied;
One should leave the evil destinies and will certainly be reborn in the heavens.
The wise know this virtue, the giver is able to give;
By giving, one attains liberation, wealth and nobility, and rebirth in the heavens.
The Buddha told the great king:
Do not have any other thoughts!

In the past, when King Nimindhara went to the Heaven of the Thirty-three, Shakra invited him to share his seat, and he enjoyed the five desires. He was still the one who set up a sacrificial hall at the city gate of Mithila and made offerings according to the Dharma, practicing giving and creating various meritorious deeds. I am that very person.
The Buddha told the great king:
It is not only by relying on this practice of giving that I attained perfect enlightenment.
Great King!
Do not have a different view, but because of practicing giving, because of arousing right faith, because of accumulating wholesome roots, I have now attained perfect enlightenment.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
I practiced giving and cultivated various meritorious deeds in order to seek unsurpassed enlightenment.
Listen attentively, O King!
Long ago, there was a king named Anandatha. The king had five sons. The youngest son was called Mirror Face.

Later, the great king's body became afflicted with illness. The physician prescribed various medicines such as roots, stems, leaves, branches, fruits, and so forth to treat him, but the illness did not improve and he became even more seriously ill.
When he was about to die, he quickly summoned his ministers:
'I am now at the end of my life and need to establish a different king.'
The ministers asked:
'Whom do you wish to establish?'
He said:ğŸ”½'My youngest son, Mirror Face.'
'Those with merit and heavenly blessings will find jeweled shoes.
The palace ladies will accept their words;
Those who see the six treasures, the inner, outer, and inner and outer treasures, the treasures between trees, mountains, and water, can be established as king.'
Having said this, he passed away.
The ministers tested which son was worthy.
Only the youngest prince, Mirror Face, was worthy to inherit the throne and had heavenly blessings.
After ascending the throne, he was given jeweled shoes and allowed to enter the palace.
The palace ladies saw him and all respected him, and he saw the six treasuries as previously described.
Up to the treasure between trees, the king stayed under a tree, and below there was a treasury.
If he was between mountains, or in the king's garden, it was the same.
The treasure in the water, when the king was playing in the water, a treasury would immediately appear.
When the ministers saw that Prince Mirror Face had such a karmic retribution, they respected and honored him and established him as king.
After he ascended the throne, he governed the country with the Dharma.

In the country there was a famine for twelve years. According to the customs, he made sacrifices and gave to all people, giving whatever they requested. Knowing his own happiness, he spoke a verse, saying:
One who obtains wealth through the Dharma, a wise person does not hoard it;
The giver is called one who upholds the precepts, giving to the receiver.
Åšramaá¹‡as and brÄhmans, the poor and destitute, I cause them to be replete;

The wise and enlightened understand this, with right faith, liberation, and mindfulness;
In giving, they are courageous and resolute, always practicing generosity without stinginess.
The Buddha told the great king:
Do not think otherwise!
The king at that time was none other than I myself.

At that time, I was King Jingmian. For twelve years, due to famine, I made universal offerings to all sentient beings, providing them with all their needs and using them for secular sacrifices. I am that very person.
Not only did I practice giving and creating meritorious karma, but I also realized unsurpassed enlightenment.
Great King!
Do not have this view, that because Jingmian practiced giving, aroused right faith, and accumulated good roots, he now attained enlightenment.
Furthermore, Great King!
In order to seek unsurpassed enlightenment, I practiced giving, created meritorious karma, and aroused the perfection of vigor.
Great King, listen carefully!
Long ago, in the country of Pancala, there were two kings:
one in the northern border and one in the southern border.

To the north, there was a king named Caisheng, whose city was called Longge. The king ruled the world with the Dharma, and the people flourished, enjoying abundance and peace. There were no deceitful thieves or epidemics, and cattle, sheep, rice, and sugarcane were abundant everywhere.
The king governed the country with the Dharma. Beside the city, there was a large pond covered with utpala flowers and other flowers, and various birds.

In the pond, there was a dragon prince named Miaosheng. He would sometimes bring forth clouds and rain, causing the fields to be rich and the harvest to be abundant. With plenty of grain stored, everyone practiced giving.
The king to the south was of a treacherous and evil nature, ruling the country with non-Dharma, constantly using shackles, imprisonment, beatings, and scolding the people.
The heavens did not bring rain, and the people were alarmed. They abandoned their homes and fled to the city of Longge in the north to seek a living.
The king of the south went out of the city to hunt and saw empty villages and destroyed temples. He asked his ministers, saying:
'Where have all the people in the village gone now?'
The ministers replied:
'Recently, due to famine, people were all starving and went to the king of the northern border.
The great king gave us fearlessness, so we will explain the causes and conditions in detail.'
The king said:
'Give you fearlessness.'
The ministers replied:

'In the northern border there is a king named Caisheng, who rules the country with the Dharma and transforms the world with the Dharma. The people are prosperous, peaceful, and wealthy. There is no deceit, theft, or epidemic. Cattle, sheep, rice, and sugarcane are abundant everywhere. He always delights in giving to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, and his enjoyment of food and supplies is abundant.
Your Majesty's nature is coarse and evil, with shackles, prohibitions, beatings, and scolding. The people are frightened and flee to the Dragon Pavilion City in the northern border.'
The king said:
'What strategies can be used to make them return to the villages to live?'
The ministers replied:
'If the great king practices compassion and benefits beings like King Dhana, in no long time all the people will flock to this city and villages.'
The ministers further said to the king:

'There is another excellent thing in that city. Beside the city there is a pond covered with lotus flowers. There are beautiful birds. There is also a dragon prince named SubhavyÅ«ha who timely sends rain, causing abundant harvests. For this reason, the people in that country are happy.'
The king again said to the ministers:
'What plan can be devised to make that dragon prince come and live here?'
The ministers said:
'If there is a person who can recite mantras, he may come.'

Then the king ordered the ministers to beat the drum and proclaim: 'If there is anyone who can recite a bright mantra to make SubhavyÅ«ha, the dragon prince in the city of Dragon Tower in the north, come to my place, I will reward him with a basket of gold and provide him with great support.'
At that time, there was a mantra master named Mantra of the Snake who came to the minister and said:
If you definitely give me this golden cage, I can use mantras to summon the wonderful dragon child to come to this place.
Then the ministers gave him the golden cage, and the mantra master said:
Wait until I have enchanted the dragon to come here, and then I will accept it.
At that time, the mantra master went to the city of the dragon palace, observed the inside of the pond on all four sides, knew where the dragon was staying, and then came back to tell the ministers:
On the seventh day, the dragon child will definitely come. You should perform the ritual of sacrifice.

At that time, the dragon child knew that the mantra master of the snake had come here and would arrive at their country on the seventh day. What plan can be made to avoid leaving their parents, relatives, and family members?
Where should they go to avoid this?
Not far from the pond, there were two hunters living:
The first was named Varaga, and the second was named Paraga. They made a living by staying by the pond, catching water and land creatures in nets.
Not long after, Varaga died.
The dragon son thought:
Now that the hunter Paraga is still alive, I must go to him.
Then the dragon son transformed into a human form, went to the hunter, and said:
Do you know why this city has such a flourishing population, abundant happiness and peace, no deceit, theft, or disease, and is filled with cattle, sheep, rice, and sugarcane everywhere?
The hunter replied:
I know this is all because the king's mind practices kindness and compassion, benefits everyone, and supports the people.
The dragon son said:
As you say, it is indeed due to the king, but there is another reason.
He replied:
'There is another reason. In this pond there is a dragon prince who rains down in a timely manner.
Because of this, the people are prosperous, joyful, and have abundant food and drink.'
The dragon prince said:
'If that dragon prince is taken away by someone, separated from his parents and relatives,
what would you do to that person when you see him?'
He replied:
'I can harm him.'
The dragon prince said:
'Do you recognize the dragon prince Wonderful Birth?'
He replied:
'I did not know him before.'
He said:

'I am the dragon prince Wonderful Birth. Now the teacher of the country of PanchalÄ in the south, named Mantra Snake, wants to come and take me away. Now he is performing a sacrificial rite to set up a boundary.
After seven days, when he comes here, he will drive in ká¹£etrapÄla stakes and tie various colored strings around the pond on all four sides. If he performs the rite, he will definitely take me away.

You should hide in one place. When you see him stirring the water from afar, you must shoot an arrow at the vital point of the mantra master. Come quickly to subdue the mantra, otherwise cut off his head.
You must first send someone to untie the mantra, then kill him.
Otherwise, I will always be bound by the mantra, and will not be able to escape until death.
Then the hunter said to the dragon prince:
If it only benefits you, I will still do it;
How could I not do it if it benefits the people of the royal city?
Please do not worry.
Then the dragon prince took the hunter to see a hidden and secluded place.
On the seventh day, the hunter went to each hidden place;

The mantra snake master then came to set up an altar, make offerings, and establish boundaries, following the mantra and mudra methods, nailing stakes on the four sides, and encircling it with various colored threads, and then shot with an arrow.
Quickly come forward and stir the water in the pond. At that time, the hunter drew his sword and said:
'In our country, there is a wonderful dragon child. You want to take him away.
If you do not quickly explain the spell, I will cut off your head with my sword and let it fall to the ground.'
At that time, the snake charmer was in pain and afraid of death. He then explained the spell for capturing.
After explaining it, the hunter cut off his life root. The dragon child was freed and came out of the pond, embracing the hunter, and said:
'You are my parents. You came to save me. I am now free from the suffering of being separated from my parents and relatives.
You can follow me to my palace.'
Then they went together into the dragon child's palace. He prepared various wonderful and excellent food and gave him a precious jewel.
He also told his parents:
'This is a relative who has been entrusted to us. Because of this person, we are now free from the suffering of being separated from our loved ones.'
At that time, the dragon's parents immediately ordered the hunter to make a wish and bestowed immeasurable precious treasures on him.
The hunter, having obtained them, then left the pond.
Not far from the pond, there was a hermit dwelling, with lush forests and various birds singing harmoniously.
However, this hermit enjoyed practicing kindness and compassion, benefiting sentient beings.
This hunter visited the hermit three times a day.
At one time, he fully explained the matter of the dragon prince.
Then the hermit said:
Why do you need precious treasures and make small wishes?
But in the dragon palace, there is a lasso that never fails. Why don't you take it?
You can go there and ask for this lasso.
Having heard this, the hunter gave rise to greedy thoughts and went to the dragon palace, where he saw the lasso and had this thought:
What I seek is this lasso.
Entering the dragon palace, he saw the wonderful dragon son again, following the other dragons.
When the dragons saw the hunter, they were overjoyed and offered him precious treasures. The hunter replied:
My treasures are sufficient. I need this snare.
The dragons said:
This snare is useless.
We keep this snare to protect ourselves from the fear of garuá¸as.
The hunter replied:
You go once every long time, so you need it once in a while;
But what I use is always in use.
If you know my kindness, you should give me this snare.
The dragon son then thought:
This person has shown me much kindness. I should now consult with my parents and give him the snare.
After the dragon son informed his parents, he gave him the snare.
When the hunter got the snare, he was overjoyed, as if he had obtained the treasures of the great earth.
After leaving the pond and returning home, the king of the city was playing with his queen, but she had not conceived for a long time.
Since they had no son or daughter, he cupped his cheek with his hand and thought to himself:
I have immeasurable wealth and treasures in my storehouses, but now I have no son to continue my lineage.
If people know I have no son, they will establish another king.
While he was thinking this, the king's relatives and Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others all wondered why the great king was so sorrowful. They said:
What are you thinking about?
The king explained in detail.
They also said to the king:
You should seek the devas, and you will have a son.

Because the king sought a son, he sought the forest spirits, garden spirits, spirits of the four-way crossroads, spirits who receive sacrifices, life-following spirits, and various good celestial spirits, wishing to have a son.
The Buddha said:
If one can obtain this by seeking, everyone would have a thousand sons.
It is necessary for the union of three things to have a child.
What are the three?
First, a father, second, a mother, and third, the presence of lust and love, then there will be a child.
Because the king was so eager to have a son, at that time a bodhisattva of the Bhadrakalpa finally conceived in the womb of the king's chief consort.
A wise woman has five kinds of wisdom.
What are the five?
First, knowing when a man has lustful thoughts, as explained in detail above.
Having known she has conceived, she joyfully informs the king:
I am now pregnant, on the left side, I am sure it is a boy.
Upon hearing this, the great king is overjoyed.
The queen thinks:
When the ten months are full, I will give birth to a child.
He will be able to support the family. After I have passed away, he will give alms according to my ability, cultivate various meritorious deeds, and make offerings to beggars;
When he is born, he will be able to follow me.

When the queen was about to give birth, she was allowed to roam freely. Cold supplies were provided for the cold, and cool supplies for the heat. She asked the doctor about the necessary clothing and food, and the six flavors were harmonized. Her body was adorned with jeweled necklaces, like a heavenly maiden, and also like the gods playing in the Joyous Garden. She always used beds, seats, and palanquins when going out, and heard pleasant sounds in fragrant and delicious places.
When the queen's month was full, she gave birth to a son, whose appearance was upright and handsome, pleasing to the eyes, and endowed with human characteristics.
At that time, the gods beat drums for entertainment. The father king heard this and was greatly startled.
The palace ladies told the king:
Because the king has a son, the gods beat drums.

The king then issued a decree to purify the city and sprinkle it, burn wonderful incense, hang jeweled banners and canopies, and give to all Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the poor and suffering. He also issued a general amnesty and made various joyful celebrations.
He also performed birthday blessings for the prince, starting from the first seven days up to the third seven days, and established a name for him.
The ministers discussed together, wanting to name him.
